title: The Qualification Data Repository (QDR): Enhancing Interoperability of Qualifications in Europe
segmentation: It was designed under the framework of ESCO.
I don't know if everyone in the room knows about Esco.
In case you do not ask.
Who is the?
European Classification of Skills, qualification and occupation.
Let's have a first look at the ESCO data model.
It's quite hope.
But Esco is based, ESCO is based on three pillars and occupation pillar skills, pillar and qualification pillar.

The way to interpolate the different pillars together or through the skills, the occupation profiles that have been developed by the ESCO Socratic it contains skills and the qualification they do contain skills through their learning outcomes.
So the idea now is for the awarding bodies to annotate the learning outcomes with skills in order to link with creepy locks together.
Before being able to develop this actual software, we had to create a meta data schema about the qualification.
The goal of this schema is to facilitate the exchange of qualification information between the stakeholders.
Across Europe and the learning opportunities and qualification anesko platforms.
The second goal is to enable the republishing of decentralized and distributed information on qualification on those platforms.
So as you can guess, it was a three step approach.
So first we did an abstract qualification data model.

Then on top of it we had an ontology mapping the information model to RDF in order to define all the vocabulary needed and they're combining semantics to describe an exchange information about qualification and last but not least, we support different exchange format and we developed next D to support the exchange of information and to further this Skype the XML file.
Let's dive into the software now.
This is the workflow of the cudia.
So you have on the left here the data providers that are either Member States of private awarding bodies.
In the center we have the datasets, qualification datasets register itself and on the right we have the consumers.
You might ask me why there is different colors here and different shapes.

In the past, the European Commission has established a previous data model that has been completely changed with the QMS, but we still have some Member States that are publishing using that old model.
So the qualification data set register will standardize the data, validate the data integrity against the QMS, and add versioning properties to the datasets.
Then the different platforms for the moment, the LQ and the ESCO platforms can manually query the API to retrieve the data set information.
So.
There are three main components on the QDR version qualification data set register.
Another component that is responsible for extracting, transforming, and loading the published qualification.
An an aggregator which follows the portals to select and merger transformed data sets and to validate them into a consistent qualification datasets.
We getting technologies.
We used RDF to capture, store and query the meta data.
We have a decade based on teologi modeling metadata of versioned data set and we have a back end treatment store.
What can the providers actually do on the platform?
Well, they can announce who they are.
So who is publishing?

They can specify what type of information they are publishing about either abstract qualification that are being developed in some Member States or individual qualification that are being developed in other Member States.
Last, but at least they can specify the location distribution and the format of the datasets.
Yes, five minutes and the data providers that are not able to host their datasets locally can upload the data sets into the qualification data set register itself.
A few words about the software characteristic the system supports up to 10 simultaneous users uploading their data set.
The ETL process takes maximum one hour and in the coming days we will have Scotland that will upload 12,000 qualification into the platform.
The hosting is done on the cloud platform maintained by digit and the physical files are hosted using Apache, the Triple Store we decided but also add to use was only.
For the data consistency, the datasets are validated against the QMS.
Ana Validation Report is generated and made available for the users.
Security is under via you log in, but.
The data set distribution is freely accessible to anyone having the URL.
The process is quite straightforward and if I have two minutes I will show it live.
We also provided documentation to all the Member States to further understand the software component itself.
What are the what are the?
Orange is well.
There are three main challenges.
The first one is for the Member States to open up the national qualification.
The datasets.

So because they have to map the national qualification framework to the European Qualification framework as well as to provide information on the set of required fields that for some of them was difficult to come up with.

The second issue, or challenges that lies is the provenance and the trust, because for the private awarding bodies is difficult to identify whether it's a trusted source of fake awarding body that would have worked fake qualification.
So we are currently looking at the possibility to access base registries in order to validate the provenance.
Last but not least, the data duplication because some qualifications are awarded into more than one country.
So for example, Microsoft Qualifications, Cisco Qualification, or Oracle qualifications.
For the future.
As I said, for the moment we have only a manual query to the API to retrieve the data sets.

the ID now is in the coming weeks to start a second development phase where we will establish an automated workflow for the Member States where they will be able to select on which platform they want to publish the qualifications.
Datasets two and the platform will then on a daily basis automatically query the API and improve the datasets.
The second part is the distributed publication.

For the moment we only have decentralized supported by the cudia, but the idea is that with this new phase, distributed publishing will be supported, so the Member States will publish a list of accredited awarding bodies and the education providers will publish information about the actual qualification that they award.
Still, I think I still have two minutes, it's perfect, it's the time of the video.
What is it not showing?
Maybe I need to?
Well, it's not displaying.
Your name please yes.
OK.
So here you can see that the Member States have to log into the system using your log in.
They need to specify information about the organization, so who they are with the administrator in the organization.
Some more information.
Then the organization is created actually into the platform.
They need to have their account activated by the European Commission.
Then they can decide to create a new data set which contains the title data set description, which is their namespace.
If they will upload or if they will host local either data set.
Then they actually make a version of the data set when they tell us which format they've been using, then there is the ETL.
Process in case it doesn't work out, there is a report that is created and that they can download.
But so far every data set was correct.
And afterwards we can see that the qualification are displayed on the European school portal.
That we also developed.
Alright, that's it.
